title: The Poincare Conjecture
description: Every simply connected, closed 3-manifold is homeomorphic to the 3-sphere. Solved by Grigori Perelman in 2002-2003 using Ricci flow with surgery.

meta.author: Grigori Perelman (2002-2003)
originalContributions: Formal statement of the Poincare Conjecture

overview.historicalContext: The Poincare Conjecture was posed in 1904 and remained open for nearly a century. Perelman proved it in 2002-2003 using Hamilton's Ricci flow, declining both the Fields Medal and the Millennium Prize.
overview.problemStatement:
**Theorem (Perelman):** Every simply connected, closed 3-manifold is homeomorphic to the 3-sphere S^3.

This was the first Millennium Prize Problem to be solved.
overview.proofStrategy: Perelman used Ricci flow with surgery: evolve the metric by the Ricci flow equation, perform surgery when singularities form, and show the manifold eventually becomes spherical or goes extinct.
keyInsights: Ricci flow evolves the metric toward constant curvature
Simply connected implies spherical in dimension 3

conclusion.summary: The Poincare Conjecture is proven: every simply connected, closed 3-manifold is a 3-sphere. This was the first Millennium Prize Problem to be solved.
conclusion.implications: Perelman's proof revolutionized geometric analysis and topology. The Ricci flow technique has since been applied to many other problems.
openQuestions: Can Ricci flow techniques generalize to higher dimensions?
What are the computational aspects of Ricci flow?
How does this connect to the geometrization conjecture?
